channel.title: Pitching an Idea: RuneScape Protocol Bot
channel.description:
I'm here pitching an idea at you guys, so we can have a nice discussion about it.
What if we (probably some others and I) were to create a protocol bot for RuneScape. In other words, what if we were to make a bot that simulates a client, but isn't actually a client. Instead, it spoofs the RuneScape protocol so well that the server couldn't tell the difference between the protocol bot and a real client? The client couldn't betray us, because it would be ours, we could send fake packets that make it 100% undetectable, it would use much less memory and CPU power, and we would be in complete control over what is going on in-game. I know the protocols change with every version, but we could just make a complicated sniffer that figures out the new protocol for the bot/etc.
If done properly, it could be the perfect bot. Post your thoughts, this is a very interesting new subject and I would like to start developing on one soon if it's possible.

item.title: Pitching an Idea: RuneScape Protocol Bot
item.dc:creator: @marluxia marluxia
item.description:
@marluxia wrote:

zstars:

I made a “proof-of-concept”-ish stand-alone packet bot not so long ago. I never managed to find a good way to auto-update it though, which is kinda why I gave up on it. I never really tried to make it indectable, and truth is it would probably be pretty hard to. (If I remember well, accounts were typically banned within 1-3 weeks, following a normal distribution centered at 2). Writing a packet bot was particularly fun though, as compared to color clickers or BCEL hacks.

Someone said something about a video of that? If it exists can you upload it please :);)???

Read full topic

item.title: Pitching an Idea: RuneScape Protocol Bot
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

unlimitedorb and frank_: I know you guys don’t get along too well, but that doesn’t mean that my thread is a place for you guys to renew your old argument. I’d appreciate it if you kept your flame and disagreements out of this as to keep this thread on track. I don’t make many threads on MITB (very few, actually), so I don’t think it’s too unreasonable to ask you guys to stay on topic and not argue with each other here. Thanks.

It seems that a proxy bot is impossible to create, because you cannot get the private RSA key in order to decrypt the ISAAC ciphers. However, the Java Math.random() is relatively predictable and there are also theories that ISAAC can be broken after a few hundred keys. I would say that emulating the client would be a better approach than acting as a proxy - it wouldn’t be too hard because most of the incoming packets could simply be discarded.

It’s very possible, and would work better than RSBot or any other bots of the sort, because Jagex can only know what is going on through the protocol - through what you tell them. If you have a packet bot, you can completely control what you tell them, and therefore completely control what they know about the “client” (bot) actions.

Runescape completely killed AutoRune and any other proxy-type bots by RSAing the login block. The only way to get the private key would be to brute force it - and good luck bruting a 128 bit key, that would take several millennia.

Read full topic
item.source: Pitching an Idea: RuneScape Protocol Bot

item.title: Pitching an Idea: RuneScape Protocol Bot
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:24, topic:284868”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=376474.msg2838508#msg2838508 date=1245812793]
so every time you run the client… which you dont because its a packet bot… you check the client… which means you have to be in the vm… which destroys the entire point of a packet bot
[/quote]
why not just store the hash of the current client version that reflects the current packet bot, and then when the server says your hash is old, update it
???[/quote]

Exactly how my version checker works.

Read full topic

item.title: Pitching an Idea: RuneScape Protocol Bot
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

Just because they modified the client and didn’t update the version, doesn’t mean the update was passive (“ninja update”). Users would still have to download the latest client. A packet bot would easily be able to detect whether or not it’s out of date.

A passive update requires that classes be defined and then loaded into the JVM or for classes to be dynamically redefined.

java.lang.instrument gives agents the ability to redefine classes on the fly, but we know the client doesn’t use agents so that’s a dead end (class redefinition is an optional JVM feature anyway).

The other option is for the client to load it using defineClass… they don’t do that either.

Autorune died because the authors didn’t review changes after an update carefully enough (or they didn’t fully understand the extent of the protocol in the first place)… not because of some nonexistent passive update feature.

Read full topic
item.source: Pitching an Idea: RuneScape Protocol Bot
